articles.headline: U.S. Struggles to Rescue Green Program Hit by Fraud
articles.snippet: A federal program intended to promote biodiesel through renewable energy credits has attracted counterfeiters and is hurting the market for smaller biodiesel producers.
articles.abstract: A federal program intended to promote biodiesel through renewable energy credits has attracted counterfeiters and is hurting the market for smaller biodiesel producers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Maryland man is awaiting sentencing for what may seem an unusual crime: selling bogus renewable energy credits and using the $9.3 million in illicit proceeds to buy jewelry and a fleet of luxury cars.

articles.headline: In Fight for a Mexican Company, a Peek Into a Tycoon’s World
articles.snippet: A legal battle between the billionaire hedge fund manager Paul E. Singer has focused a light on David Martinez, a Mexican financier who lives a rarefied but mysterious life in Manhattan.
articles.abstract: A legal battle between the billionaire hedge fund manager Paul E. Singer has focused a light on David Martinez, a Mexican financier who lives a rarefied but mysterious life in Manhattan.
articles.lead_paragraph: High above Columbus Circle, atop the Time Warner Center, is one of the most expensive apartments in Manhattan, a sleek aerie of steel and stone, high windows and soaring views.

articles.headline:
Panetta Warns of
Dire Threat of
Cyberattack on U.S.
articles.snippet: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta warned that the United States was facing the possibility of a “cyber-Pearl Harbor” and was increasingly vulnerable to foreign computer hackers.
articles.abstract: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta warned that the United States was facing the possibility of a “cyber-Pearl Harbor” and was increasingly vulnerable to foreign computer hackers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta warned Thursday that the United States was facing the possibility of a “cyber-Pearl Harbor” and was increasingly vulnerable to foreign computer hackers who could dismantle the nation’s power grid, transportation system, financial networks and government.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: The Classics-to-Be for Tomorrow’s Car Collectors
articles.snippet: Three automotive journalists nominated their favorite cars as the contenders to replace five classics at the car shows of the future.
articles.abstract: Three automotive journalists nominated their favorite cars as the contenders to replace five classics at the car shows of the future.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S hard to know which creative works will endure. Which current pop songs will be played at nostalgia-themed parties 20 years from now. Which movie quotations will join the ranks of “Luke, I am your father” or “We’re gonna need a bigger boat.” And which cream puffs will be proudly displayed at classic-car shows a generation from now.
articles.byline: By Ezra Dyer, Keith Martin and Phil Patton

articles.headline: In Haiti, Little Can Be Found of a Hip-Hop Artist’s Charity
articles.snippet: The charity created by Wyclef Jean, the Haitian-born hip-hop celebrity, effectively went out of business last month, leaving a trail of debts, unfinished projects and broken promises.
articles.abstract: The charity created by Wyclef Jean, the Haitian-born hip-hop celebrity, effectively went out of business last month, leaving a trail of debts, unfinished projects and broken promises.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — In a new memoir, Wyclef Jean, the Haitian-born hip-hop celebrity, claims he endured a “crucifixion” after the Jan. 12, 2010, earthquake when he faced questions about his charity’s financial record and ability to handle what eventually amounted to $16 million in donations.

articles.headline: When a Crisis Comes With a Reset Button
articles.snippet: Once a pillar of stable demand, Europe faces the same overcapacity issues that plagued the American market a few years ago, but now United States auto sales are soaring.
articles.abstract: Once a pillar of stable demand, Europe faces the same overcapacity issues that plagued the American market a few years ago, but now United States auto sales are soaring.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONCE again, the global auto industry is discovering that America is still the best place in the world to make money selling cars.

articles.headline: Biden and Ryan Quarrel Aggressively in Debate, Offering Contrasts
articles.snippet: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Representative Paul D. Ryan engaged in a fluent and combative exchange over the Obama administration’s handling of foreign affairs and the nation’s economic recovery.
articles.abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Representative Paul D. Ryan engaged in a fluent and combative exchange over the Obama administration’s handling of foreign affairs and the nation’s economic recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: DANVILLE, Ky. — It was the debate that President Obama and Mitt Romney did not have a week ago.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Biden vs. Ryan: No Shy People Onstage
articles.snippet: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Representative Paul D. Ryan held their positions tenaciously and delineated battle lines that had been blurred when President Obama and Mitt Romney met a week ago.
articles.abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Representative Paul D. Ryan held their positions tenaciously and delineated battle lines that had been blurred when President Obama and Mitt Romney met a week ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was the Young Gun against the Old Hand, the reformer ready to turn the page on an aging social compact that dates to the New Deal jousting with the veteran — alive for much of that compact’s construction — defending the tried and true.

articles.headline: Mortgage Lending Helps JPMorgan Profit Rise 34%
articles.snippet: JPMorgan Chase posted earnings of $5.7 billion, up from $4.3 billion, as the bank showed signs of strength in consumer and corporate lending.
articles.abstract: JPMorgan Chase posted earnings of $5.7 billion, up from $4.3 billion, as the bank showed signs of strength in consumer and corporate lending.
articles.lead_paragraph: Finally moving beyond a trading debacle that has stained his once-stellar reputation, Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, on Friday trumpeted a strong quarter of earnings stemming from a surge in mortgage lending.

articles.headline: University Endowments Face a Hard Landing
articles.snippet: Most institutions are pursuing alternative investments, which have been underperforming a simple mix of stocks and bonds in recent years.
articles.abstract: Most institutions are pursuing alternative investments, which have been underperforming a simple mix of stocks and bonds in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, America’s largest, richest and most prestigious universities have been the envy of investors. They churned out double-digit returns over the last two decades, even with steep losses during the financial crisis. Harvard’s endowment today is over $30 billion and has generated annualized returns of 12.5 percent over the last 20 years.
